Conference Held
on Soviet Jewry
in Washington
A conference on Soviet
Jewry will be held in
Washington next week, and the
Inter-Campus Council has
organized free transportation
for students interested in
attending.
The conference will run next
Wednesday and Thursday. The
ICC, a group consisting of
Jewish students from all colleges in Baltimore, will provide
buses to the event on Wednesday evening, and will return
Thursday evening, according to
Rob Zeldin, Chairman of the
ICC.
The conference, which
Zeldin anticipates will be attended by 800-1000 students
from about 41 states, is an annual event run by the Student
Coalition on Soviet Jewry.
There is no fee for attending
the conference, and accomodations will be provided free.
Those interested in attending
should contact Faith Katz, who
is organizing the trip for the
ICC, at 825-4523.
On Wednesday night, the
participants will be addressed
by several speakers, while on
Thursday they will have prearranged meetings with •their
Congressman or Senator.
Zeldin said a special concern of
the conference is "refusniks".
These are jews who refuse to
leave the Soviet Union and
emigrate to Israel.
This is the eighth annual conference of its kind, according to
Zeldin.

h. Leslie Matthews. M.D.

Union Memorial Hospital
Sports Medicine Center
Arthroscopy is a medical
term which means "looking into a joint."
The term refers to a relatively new procedure which allows
a physician to visually inspect
the internal aspect of a joint by
utilizing a small fiberoptic
telescope ("arthroscope"). This
instrument is introduced into
the joint through a small punc1
4 inch
ture site approximately /
in length. By maneuvering the
arthroscope within the joint,
the entire interior aspect of the
joint can be directly inspected
for abnormalities.
Historically, the technique of
arthroscopy was originated in
Japan in the early 1960's. The
technique was quickly adopted
by several surgeons in the
United States but it was not until several technological advancements were made that the
procedure became more widely utilized. With the development of fiberoptics, better lens
systems, and better instrument
design, clear and relatively easy
visualization of the internal
aspects of the joints then
became possible.
' As the knee joint is the
largest joint in the body and is
relatively prone to injury, arthroscopy was first utilized extensively in the diagnosis of
knee disorders. Knee disorders

remain the most common joint
abnormality for which arthroscopic techniques are
employed.
The arthroscope has now proven itself to be invaluable in the
diagnosis of a variety of knee
conditions including meniscal
tears ("torn cartilage"), loose
bodies, ligament injuries, and
arthritis. Because arthroscopy
allows for direct visualization
of the joint, in experienced
hands it has reduced the need
for indirect tests such as arthrograms (dye injections into
the joint with x-rays).
Art hroscopic surgery is a
technique by which surgery can
be performed using the arthroscope. In this technique,
small instruments are introduced inside the joint through
other punctures and surgery is
performed under the direct
visualization afforded by the
arthroscope. Utilizing this
technique, such procedures as
removal of a torn menisci,
loose bodies, and bone spurs
can be accomplished, thus
eliminating the need for conventional open sugery.
The procedure itself can
usually be performed on an
outpatient basis. Arthroscopy is
performed in an operating
room under sterile conditions.
While art hroscopy of the knee
can be performed under local
(Novocaine) anesthesia, it is
usually done under general
anesthesia. The arthroscope
(and other instruments if need-

ed)are introduced into the knee
through small puncture sites,
each requiring only one stitch to
close following the procedure.
With current technology, a
small TV camera can be attached to the scope to allow for
visualization of the procedure
on a TV monitor. Video tapes
of the procedure can thereby be
made for permanent records.
Following arthroscopic
surgery, most patients are able
to walk immediately, requiring
the use of a cane or crutches for
a few days only. Most patients
are able to return to athletic activity within four to six weeks
following this procedure,
depending on the type of problem encountered and the type
of procedure performed.
Since the techniques for arthroscopy and arthroscopic
surgery of the knee have proven
themselves to be significant advances in medical technology,
investigation is ongoing to
assess the role of these techniques in other joint disorders.
The use of arthroscopy to
diagnose and treat certain
shoulder disorders has already
proven itself to be effective.
Arthroscopy has been successfully performed on other
joints as well, such as the ankle,
elbow, and wrist. However, the
relatively small size and tight
configuration of these joints
makes the procedure more difficult and often less rewarding.
As further experience is gained
and tecimology evolves, these

present limitations may be
overcome.
Finally, it must be pointed
out that arthroscopy and arthroscopic surgery are not applicable to every knee disorder.
Some knee injuries and diseases
require no surgery while others
still require the routine
operative procedures for treatment. When appropriate,
however, art hroscopy and arthroscopic surgery offer the advantages of fewer risks to the
patient and reduced recovery
time which can be especially important for athletes.

Arthroscope Revolutionizes Treatment Of Knee Disorders
h. Leslie Matthews. M.D.

Union Memorial Hospital
Sports Medicine Center
Arthroscopy is a medical
term which means "looking into a joint."
The term refers to a relatively new procedure which allows
a physician to visually inspect
the internal aspect of a joint by
utilizing a small fiberoptic
telescope ("arthroscope"). This
instrument is introduced into
the joint through a small punc1
4 inch
ture site approximately /
in length. By maneuvering the
arthroscope within the joint,
the entire interior aspect of the
joint can be directly inspected
for abnormalities.
Historically, the technique of
arthroscopy was originated in
Japan in the early 1960's. The
technique was quickly adopted
by several surgeons in the
United States but it was not until several technological advancements were made that the
procedure became more widely utilized. With the development of fiberoptics, better lens
systems, and better instrument
design, clear and relatively easy
visualization of the internal
aspects of the joints then
became possible.
' As the knee joint is the
largest joint in the body and is
relatively prone to injury, arthroscopy was first utilized extensively in the diagnosis of
knee disorders. Knee disorders

remain the most common joint
abnormality for which arthroscopic techniques are
employed.
The arthroscope has now proven itself to be invaluable in the
diagnosis of a variety of knee
conditions including meniscal
tears ("torn cartilage"), loose
bodies, ligament injuries, and
arthritis. Because arthroscopy
allows for direct visualization
of the joint, in experienced
hands it has reduced the need
for indirect tests such as arthrograms (dye injections into
the joint with x-rays).
Art hroscopic surgery is a
technique by which surgery can
be performed using the arthroscope. In this technique,
small instruments are introduced inside the joint through
other punctures and surgery is
performed under the direct
visualization afforded by the
arthroscope. Utilizing this
technique, such procedures as
removal of a torn menisci,
loose bodies, and bone spurs
can be accomplished, thus
eliminating the need for conventional open sugery.
The procedure itself can
usually be performed on an
outpatient basis. Arthroscopy is
performed in an operating
room under sterile conditions.
While art hroscopy of the knee
can be performed under local
(Novocaine) anesthesia, it is
usually done under general
anesthesia. The arthroscope
(and other instruments if need-

ed)are introduced into the knee
through small puncture sites,
each requiring only one stitch to
close following the procedure.
With current technology, a
small TV camera can be attached to the scope to allow for
visualization of the procedure
on a TV monitor. Video tapes
of the procedure can thereby be
made for permanent records.
Following arthroscopic
surgery, most patients are able
to walk immediately, requiring
the use of a cane or crutches for
a few days only. Most patients
are able to return to athletic activity within four to six weeks
following this procedure,
depending on the type of problem encountered and the type
of procedure performed.
Since the techniques for arthroscopy and arthroscopic
surgery of the knee have proven
themselves to be significant advances in medical technology,
investigation is ongoing to
assess the role of these techniques in other joint disorders.
The use of arthroscopy to
diagnose and treat certain
shoulder disorders has already
proven itself to be effective.
Arthroscopy has been successfully performed on other
joints as well, such as the ankle,
elbow, and wrist. However, the
relatively small size and tight
configuration of these joints
makes the procedure more difficult and often less rewarding.
As further experience is gained
and tecimology evolves, these

present limitations may be
overcome.
Finally, it must be pointed
out that arthroscopy and arthroscopic surgery are not applicable to every knee disorder.
Some knee injuries and diseases
require no surgery while others
still require the routine
operative procedures for treatment. When appropriate,
however, art hroscopy and arthroscopic surgery offer the advantages of fewer risks to the
patient and reduced recovery
time which can be especially important for athletes.

This week's quiz is about all those wimpy
groups you used to listen to but won't admit to anymore. Don't be discouraged by the
amount of words you see printed to the left;
these eight questions are long only because
they're chock full o' clues. Answer them as
best you can, and get your entry to the
Gatehouse by Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Good
luck, Bee Gees-breath!

RESULTS
1) The lead singer of this early 70's band was also the singer of the theme for a hit movie starring Richard Dreyfuss
and Marsha Mason. Name this band and one of their big hits, and you're on your way toward winning the dough.
2) These two wimpy brothers both went from TV to pop stardom overnight and seemed to disappear just as quickly.
One was popular in the early 70's, while the younger brother hit in the latter part of the decade. Name the early bird,
and his mysterious brother, as well as their respective TV shows.
3) Although this keyboardist claims to be a former Beach Boy, he has never been seen in the same picture with any
of the wimpy Wilsons. As part of a very wimpy duo, he hit number one with a song written by yet another wimp,
who would probably be easy to break up with. Name the wimpy duo, the wimpy songwriter, and the wimpy song.
4) Reg Dwight is the real name of this big wimp, who tries to pass himself off as an athlete. One of his biggest hits
was dedicated to the World Team Tennis squad which featured Billy Jean King. Name the well dressed wimp, who
just married a woman (!), and the song.
5) Here's the lyric, name the song:
"I heard his fiancee got a letter that told how Billy died that day. The letter said that
he was a_bero. I heard she threw the letter away."
Poignant, huh? Name the group, too.
6) First he was cool, then he became a wimp, then he got fat. That should be all the clues that you need, but here's
one more: His former live-in lover is now married to a former olympic athlete, who is himself a wimp.
7) In the early 70's, this singing family hit with a remake of the old Drifters' tune "Save the Last Dance For Me,"
as well as one other monster, before fading into obscurity. Name the group,fronted by wimpy heartthrob Tony, and
their big hit.
8) In their early days, this band was know as The Choir, and scored a regional hit with "It's Cold Outside." In the
early 70's, they changed their name, started begging girls to have sex in their songs, and went all the way to the top
of the charts. Their lead singer went on to a solo career, hitting with "All by Myself." Name this fruity group, and
one of their big hits.
Bonus: 1) Did the Monkees play their own instruments?
2) Name the wimpiest Beatle.
